bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 12, 1940

div1.p: Moran informs Hench that he is sure that he has found the Camp Lazear infected-clothing building, and has investigated the acquisition of the building and surrounding land.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 12, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Oct. 12, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
THERE IS NOT A SHADOW OF DOUBT but that the old shack is Build-
ing No. 1, the “Infected Clothing Building”, originally baptized “The
Infected Bedding & Clothing Building”.

Yesterday, accompanied by our good and genial friend, Sr. Luis
Pogolotti, I went over the camp site and surroundings for the STEENTH
time. We measured the building inside and out and it is, to all intents
and purposes, 14 by 20 feet, the double board wall absorbing any little
difference between the inside and outside measurements, as you will see
by the enclosed pencil drawing made by Sr. Pogolotti.

Cuban wooden buildings do not have any such form of ceiling as
exist in this building. If they have any ceiling at all, they would
extend all the way up, forming an inverted V, leaving no such enclosed
triangle as the old shack has. Most of the original flooring still
exists, the deteriorated boards having been replaced by new or used
boards, from time to time. Entering the front door, an aperture in the
ceiling, in the left hand corner, indicates where the stovepipe went
through the roof. The old lady who now occupies the house thought Sr. Z.
had a stove under it. On our way back to the city, I casually dropped by
Sr. Z's house, informing him that the old shack was what we were looking
for except that it had a round hole in the ceiling which either his father
or himself must have made there for a stovepipe. Quick as a flash, he
said that the hole in the ceiling had been there always and that he had
never seen a stove there during his father's lifetime nor since. Even
though he had informed me that the aperture was made by his father or by
himself, I would still be convinced that the main part of the shack is
original. You know, of course, that there was a stove in the original
Building No. 1. All that is lacking is the “double vestibule”, the
window on the left hand side, having been enlarged slightly and extended
clear down to the floor and iron-barred, shuttered by a door which opens
inward. The porch was added and the double vestibule removed entirely
and replaced by a wide door, to be seen in outline in my photo No. 26.
A room was added on to the end of it, the floor of which is lower than
that of the original shack, but communicating with the room against which
it was built. A kitchen, the length of the original building, has been
built against the rear wall. This has a concrete floor. I never dreamed,
when we failed to examine this building thoroughly, that even a single
board of it could last forty years.

Regardless of what the record may claim as to the direction in
which this building faced, it is the original building, alright. It is
probably 75% facing South, 25% East. Sr. Pogolotti and I arrived at the
conclusion that Sra. Rojas and her relative could see the line of tents
on the higher ground, around where she and I were photographed together
in the condition the farm was in, in 1900, but she could not see either
of the two shacks from the roof of the farmhouse. It is also entirely
possible that the larger number of tents the 2nd Regiment of N. C. Inf.
which had their camp in the “Finca”, in 1898-99, were those that they
remembered so clearly. The latter regiment had returned to the U. S.
long before Camp Lazear was thought of. You will see the entry in Dr.
Rojas' book about this Regiment, when I send you the photostatic copy.
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 2 --
Oct. 12, 1940.
These are promised to me in time to make the Monday AIRMAIL, which closes
at 1:00 P. M. When I suggested taking the book to the U. S. I was quick
to note that Miss Rojas and her mother would not be very agreeable to
such a proposition, so I hastened to suggest that she trust me with the
book in order to have photostatic copies made of the entries concerned. To
this she readily agreed, allowing me to take the book with me. I then made
a beeline for the photographer who specializes in that class of work, on
Calle Obispo. The next day (today) being a holiday, followed by Sunday,
the photographer told me the best he could do would be to make the photostats
for me first thing Monday morning. There are altogether 8 entries on 8
different pages and these are to be photographed in their entirety. Trans-
lations, I hope, will be ready on Monday morning, in which case I will try
to have them included with the photostats.

My reference to the concrete slabs on the spot where Building No.
2 WAS requires a little further explanation, if I have not mentioned it in
one of my recent letters or in the 7-page memorandum I sent you. I asked
Mr. Z. “how come” that the building had a cement floor. He told me that
the site upon which building No. 2 was erected was extremely damp, while
Building No. 1 stands on limestone formation. The floor of No. 2 began to
rot several years ago and his father had it replaced by a concrete one.

With reference to the trees in and around Building No. 1, you will
notice from your Photo No. 17-b that there were no trees at all around the
building. Sr. Z. says that those trees were planted there by his father
to shade the building, so that none of the trees you and I saw there are
more than 40 years old. That sound reasonable enough, since poplar and
laurel trees grow very rapidly in this country. The poplar tree is no
longer in vogue in the Vedado section of Havana since its roots play havoc
with the sidewalks and the “Alamos” are a constant headache to the electric
light company which once a year is obliged to cut off the limbs and branches
in order to clear their lines. The laurel tree is being planed by house
owners to save their sidewalks but the electric light company's problem is
not solved by this measure. The two laurel trees in front of our house
have been ruthlessly cut down to “stumps” each year of the four odd since we
moved to our present residence. Laurel trees planted around the corner, on
27th Street, near our house, after we moved to where we now live, are today
as tall as the 2-storey building which they shade. You can readily imagine
that trees planted even ten years ago, around Building No. 1, would be
giants by this time.

What kind
of trees there
now

I mentioned in a recent letter, or in my “observations” on your
37-page memorandum, that Sr. Pogolotti told Mrs. Phillips of the tacit
acknowledgement of the Cuban authorities that they had erred in placing
Camp Lazear where it WAS NOT. Sr. Pogolotti informs me that Mrs. P.
either misunderstood him or that I misunderstood her. He has not spoken
to any of them on the subject, so he says. Therefore, I will have to eat
my words in this connection. You have not informed me as to whether or
not I should interview Dr. Ramos, nor as to his reply, if any, to your
letter dated August 28th. I would like to know what line of argument you
wish me to pursue in your behalf, in this matter. If they pass up the
ROJAS BOOK EVIDENCE, I see very little use of arguing with them. I am in-
clined to think that THEY WILL NOT ride rough shod over it. It is of too
conclusive a nature. Señorita Lidia Cabrera (friend of the Rojas family)
suggested that we could take the matter up with Colonel Batista, should
they prove too recalcitrant, and that we would undoubtedly win out.

I confided the entire matter of your proposed acquisition of the
shack and a portion of the ground around it for a memorial or shrine. He
assures me that the owner of the property, a Sr. Macía (I think that was
the name), a good friend of his, would not “hold you up”, even opining that
he might make you a gift of the shack as well as the land. I AM NOT SO
OPTIMISTIC, but I may be wrong. I felt that I could serve your purpose
better thru Sr. Pogolotti than by acting on my own account. He has been most
unselfish in this matter throughout. He will endeavor to see Sr. Macía on
Monday or Tuesday and will let me know the result of his interview. As soon
as I have anything tangible to report, I will pass it on to you by Airmail.

I found that I had “cheated” you out of the seven negatives of the
last photos I had taken (which I consider the most important), so I am
sending them to you by airmail of Sunday, the 13th., by which this letter
will also go to you, since I am finishing it on Sunday morning. I went to
Mass before I came down to the office. “Remember that thou keep holy the
Sabbath Day”.

Will try to enclose the “Ignacio Agramonte” stamps with this letter.
This Agramonte was a General in the Cuban Army of Liberation but I cannot tell
you whether or not he was related to Dr. Aristides Agramonte. Will try to
find out and report to you before you leave the Mayo Clinic for W. & J.
I thought there was some reference to it in Dr. Agramonte's article. Just
got the relationship, over the telephone from one of the Agramonte clan.
Dr. Agramonte was the son of a cousin of GENERAL IGNACIO AGRAMONTE. Dr.
Agramonte's father was killed in action during Cuba's wars for independence,
following which (at a tender age), the widow took him to the U. S. where
they lived and where Dr. Agramonte was educated from primary school to
graduation as an M. D. at Columbia. There you have it.

WHAT AM I TO DO WITH THE WOOD FROM THE FRAMBOYAN TREE NEAR BLDG.
NO. 1?

I think I have given you some information and CONSIDERABLE mis-
information. If you think the other fellow better posted in some matters,
accept his information and data. MY OPINION, in many instances, are ONLY
my own opinion, most of it coming from memory rather than data accumulated
by me. I should have kept a Diary, but that wish comes rather late.
